thread.title: Gift Guide: 17 Smart Presents For College Students
thread.title_full: Gift Guide: 17 Smart Presents For College Students - Forbes

author: Vanessa McGrady
title: Gift Guide: 17 Smart Presents For College Students
text:
This is half of a two-part story. Read the other half, Does Your College-Bound Kid Have These 11 Basics?
It’s natural to want to ply your college-bound child with gifts, but one thing to consider is that everything he or she brings to college “must fit in a space slightly larger than a Mini Cooper,” says Harry H. Harrison, Jr. , a New York Times best-selling author of parenting books and books about preparing teens for adulthood, including “1001 Things Every College Student Needs to Know.” For that reason alone, it’s best to choose items that are beautiful, practical or a combination of the two .
Here are some gifts that say, “I love you” when you can’t be there in person :
1. The polite reminder: A personalized pillow nags when you can’t by reminding your student about family birthdays in the most attractive way possible. $39.99
2. The hard press: The Le Creuset French press comes in a stoneware version, better able to withstand groggy mornings and late-night handling. $64.95
3. Pack it up: Go with a high-end Frye heirloom backpack ($298) that will last well past the final round of finals, or a more practical eBags option ($99.99) for those who can use a little organizational support. Here’s a great backpack roundup from GearPatrol.com for serious shoppers.
4. Shower sure: Get a multipocket tote and fill it with flip flops, toothpaste, toothbrush, razors and other daily ablution needs. $5.99
5. Serious sound: Everyone knows that classical music can help you sleep and study better, which is the official reason to buy the Sonos Playbar (even though it guarantees your kid’s room will become party central). Play any digital song from anywhere and beam it out via wireless speakers. $699
6. Food containers: There comes a time in many a college kid’s life when the food situation comes down to macaroni and lentils. Food storage jars with chalk-written labels help them properly store and identify their dry food and grains. From $7.99
Page 1 / 3 Continue
